Posts.Content: If your husband was in Vietnam during this time, in country, boots on the ground he should qualify for benefits. His best bet is to take his DD214 and any military documentation that he has to a veterans group. I use the DAV. They will be his advocate and process his claim. It is quicker to do it this way and if you are denied a claim they will do the appeal. fasteddie USN

Posts.Title: Anyone using Human Growth Hormones after RP to improve health?

Posts.Content: Hello Your situation needs to be moved on quickly. Gleason 9 is very agressive and requires an excellent large medical center or a university cancer treatment center that you can probably find in a large city near you. These institutions will have all of the options available to you. I would recommend that you start reading Dr. Walsh"s, book Surviving Prostate Cancer and ask lots of questions. This will help you understand the lingo of prostate cancer. The possible involvement of the lymph node needs a biopsy to really determine the extent of cancer involvement. Have your dad start walking and exercising and doing his kegals. This will help him with whatever option he choses. This is not your grandfathers prostate cancer and the medical advancements over the last 10 years are giving lots of hope for advanced staged prostate cancer. Peace and Grace Ed

Posts.Title: Father t3c need advice

Posts.Content: Krugzz, it is unfortunate that you are now part of this club. Slow down and take a deep breath. You have time to explore your options and you need to inform yourself to the max. If you chose surgery find the best surgeon in your area. If it is robotic, make sure he has 300+ surgeries and a good reputation. You may want to explore a cancer treatment center like MD Anderson, Loma Linda, Mayo, ect. Places like these have a wealth of experience and excellent outcomes. Grab a copy of Walsh's book and read it cover to cover. I would also encourage you to see an excellent raditation oncologist for their opinon. PCa is a life changer!!! Remember you want to get rid of the cancer first. Then maintain control of your urination. Thirdly, a young man your age needs to consider his sex life. Trust but verify and get ready to live with the choice of treatment you choose. Get yourself a folder and get a copy of everything done to this date and in the future. Also take notes on everything the doctors say and ask alot of questions. You didn't indicate if you are married. If so include her in everything. Peace and Grace Ed

Posts.Title: Joined the Club

Posts.Content: Redcc, I can personally empathize and I am sorry about your mum and dad's situation. My wife had BC in 2011 and I had PCa in 2012. It makes for a tough year when both of you are running the cancer gauntlet at the same time. It is good that you are there for them. They might well need your help. I agree with newporter finding a good prostate oncologist is critically important. I didn't see where your dad is from, his age, or cancer specifics. If you continue on this sight you may want to post your dad's signature (PCa info). Maybe someone on this sight can give you the name of an excellent Dr. in your area. Mine is Dr. Matt Lauer. Met with him at UNM Cancer Treatment Center in Albq. NM. after my surgery. I have him on speed dial if my PSA starts back up. Lastly, your statement that your dad is terminal could be a long way off. It is amazing what is happening in the PCa treatment world with drugs and treatments that significantly extend life. Our thoughts and prayers are with you and your parents. Peace and Grace Ed

Posts.Title: Surgery Tomorrow

Posts.Content: Chief, good to hear you made it through the surgery ok. I had very similar problems, but spent 6 days in hospital due to a complication. I used half of a pad and tape to wrap around the penis and catheter to absorb the leakage. The rest will heal quickly once you get the catheter out. My wife was the first girl I kissed when I got back from Vietnam and has stuck by me through thick and thin. If you start walking a couple miles a day, watch what you eat and do your kegals life will get back to normal fairly soon. I am at six months and the sex issue is alittle complicated but can be managed. That has probably been the biggest transition for me physically and mentally and is getting better with time. Make sure you hug and kiss her alot and say thankyou dear. She has been through alot.

Posts.Title: Day Three After Surgery

Posts.Content: Fran, your situation isn't unusal. It takes time and keep doing your kegals. I am still wearing half a pad after one year for stress continence. It was almost 3 months after surgery before I started to get some control while standing. Since you have control lying down shows some progress. My urologist considers my one pad a day or folded paper towel as continence. Alot of the time my problem is my own doing. I shouldn't drink two cups of coffee a day, one or two beers, a soda, or orange juice. Water is the best fluid of choice, less irritation. Sometimes medications can cause less control. Give it time, you will get better. Peace and Grace Ed

Posts.Title: Incontinence issue.

Posts.Content: Fran, I failed to mention that walking until my pad overflowed was a big help. You need to strengthen your pelvic floor muscles. For a while I just walked up and down my street to stay close to my home restroom. Being forced to try and hold it is unconfortable, but I had to get use to it and it got better. Now I walk and run on my treadmill and lift weights, strength is your friend, but it all causes minor leaks. I guess it is the price I will have to pay to be PCa free for the moment. Peace and Grace Ed

Posts.Title: Incontinence issue.

Posts.Content: If I were you, I would find a good urologist who prides himself on giving an excellent DRE. Your DRE needs to be longer than 15 seconds, at least a minute, and the longer your urologist's finger is the better. I know this sounds alittle gross, but better to be safe than sorry. I had low PSA's and a Gleason 9. Get this done ASAP and when it comes back in your favor, then you have it behind you. No pun intended. Happy Trails Ed

Posts.Title: Just diagnosed with cancer

Posts.Content: Haliday, so sorry to hear about your situation. Please read Dr. Walsh's book and highlight what relates to your situaton and ask lots of questions. You need to start keeping a folder with all the path reports, test results, past history, ect. I would also take copius notes on everything the Dr. says and get copies of his notes. This can be a very confusing process and it gets complicated. Please post in the signature relative medical information. For most of us on this site this was the most important medical decision we have ever had to make and we only got one chance to get it right. Looking at what you have already shared is a case that could need immediated attention. It sounds like you have some good Dr.'s in your corner, so get er done as soon as possible. Wishing you both the best. Peace and Grace Ed

Posts.Content: Hey Doc! What are you drinking. You may need to cut out fluids that irritate. Coffee, soda, orange juice. I found that my vitamin C tablets added to my problem. You may want to stick with water for a few weeks to see if this helps. My urologist had to open up my meatus because it had narrowed significantly and was causing a restriction and painful urination. He may need to scope you and see if you have any problems. Sorry to hear that you have joined the club, but having a physcian on board gives us some medical expertise. Peace and Grace Ed

Posts.Content: I have noticed that many have their pathology reports a permanent part of their posts. Where do I go in the sight to set this up?
Posts.Title: Where do you post your path reports so that they come up on the page when you post?

Posts.Content: Sorry to hear that you have joined the club. It's amazing what they can do with PC today and it gets better everyday with medical advancements. Try to slow down and catch your breath. You need to inform yourself about what options are available to you. I would encourage you to pick up a copy of Dr. Walsh's, Surviving Prostate Cancer, a highlighter and read it from cover to cover. Information about what your dealing with will guide you in making the right decision for yourself. PC is like a finger print, no two are alike. Your age is working in your favor, so get the best medical advice available to you. I am partial to university medical centers and cancer treatment centers for treatment. I used both. Check out all of your options. You have time to work through this in an orderly and precise manner. If you have in questions, bring them to the folks here. Very knowledgable bunch and they helped me out alot when I was going through my trial by PC. Hang in there. Peace and Grace Ed

Posts.Content: A small nodule can be the tip of the iceberg. Low PSA can be an indicator of a potentially aggressive cancer. My highest PSA was 1.8 and I had a small nodule. The PSA had doubled from the previous year and the final surgical pathology was Gleason 9. You have to work through this as soon as possible. Good luck on the results and hopefully you won't have to be a member of the club. Peace and Grace Ed

Posts.Content: A small nodule can be the tip of the iceberg. Low PSA can be an indicator of a potentially aggressive cancer. My highest PSA was 1.8 and I had a small nodule. The PSA had doubled from the previous year and the final surgical pathology was Gleason 9. You have to work through this as soon as possible. Good luck on the results and hopefully you won't have to be a member of the club. Peace and Grace Ed

Posts.Title: Nodule with Low PSA

Posts.Content: Sorry to hear that you have joined the club. It's amazing what they can do with PC today and it gets better everyday with medical advancements. Try to slow down and catch your breath. You need to inform yourself about what options are available to you. I would encourage you to pick up a copy of Dr. Walsh's, Surviving Prostate Cancer, a highlighter and read it from cover to cover. Information about what your dealing with will guide you in making the right decision for yourself. PC is like a finger print, no two are alike. Your age is working in your favor, so get the best medical advice available to you. I am partial to university medical centers and cancer treatment centers for treatment. I used both. Check out all of your options. You have time to work through this in an orderly and precise manner. If you have in questions, bring them to the folks here. Very knowledgable bunch and they helped me out alot when I was going through my trial by PC. Hang in there. Peace and Grace Ed

Posts.Content: Your husband's situation is difficult to say the least. The mental difficulties and depression compound the problem. Regarding pads you may want to try the Walmart men's guards(pads) maximum absorbency in a whitety tighty with a pair of plastic pants. It has only been 3 months since his surgery and in my case it took 6 months before I felt like I was getting some control. The coffee, beer, soda, orange juice and some medications can have devastating effect on continence. I wish that someone could convince him that water is his best friend. My wife bought me small trash can with a popup lid and I put the pads in it and emptied it twice a day to control odor. Your doctor may have other options for you, so hang in there and continue to encourage your husband to try harder to control his incontinence. Question, does your husband have problems holding his urine when he is laying down in bed while sleeping, or when sitting watching TV?

Posts.Title: Question for the wives and one for the men re incontinence.

Posts.Content: This is major surgery and you will want to stay a couple of days close to your surgeon and hospital. I spent 6 days in the hospital after my surgery due to complications. I was walking the halls 8 hours after surgery, felt fine, looked forward to going home the next day. Then I had problems with fluid retention, and all hell broke loose. So do yourself a favor and slow way down. Your surgeon will be calling the shots and I doubt that he will let you get to far away. Peace and Grace Ed

Posts.Content: Hello That hard area is very important to monitor. Mine went from a hard spot to a nodule in six months and turned out to be cancer. Recheck in a few months with a different urologist and a second biopsy is a good idea. The biopsy cores can miss the cancer. Kind of like throwing darts at the board and missing the bullseye if the cancer is small.

Posts.Title: blood after biopsy

Posts.Content: Stay close to your urologist. Things can change rapidly with PCa. My Dr. first noticed (DRE) a hardness on the prostate and the next year felt a 11mm lump. Then we were off to the races. Everyone is different when it comes to their personal PCa experience. My PSA never got above 1.86 and after surgery the final pathology was a Gleason 9. Your father having PCa lends credance to actively pursuing this issue on a regular basis. You don't want to let it get away from you. If you have a good prostate cancer treatment center in your area you might want to check in and get a second opinion and maybe another biopsy if recommended. The folks on this site are straight shooters. Been there and got there t-shirts. Worry little until you have a definite and live life alot. I had my prostate removed a year ago. In two weeks I am going on another bow elk hunt in Northern New Mexico and will be humping ridges at 10,000 ft, for a 340 or bigger bull. Get yourself a bucket list and get it on. Peace and Grace Ed

Posts.Title: Is either center better than the other

Posts.Content: DDBNY, a few suggestions. Get yourself a folder and start collecting pathology reports, past and present PSA tests, biopsy reports, radiation treatment information and collect the business card from everyone your dad comes in contact with that is handling his medical care. Ask your dad to sign a medical release form for all of his medical information. Look over the material and get a copy of Dr. Walsh's book and a highlighter and read. Also, see if your dad will let you attend his Dr. appointments, take lots notes and ask lots of questions. As you get this information put it on the site and pretinent information into the signature. Your dad's case has moved rapidly and he needs information to make the best informed decision for himself. It takes two to be sick and your dad is very fortunate to have you by his side. Being stubborn and private is the personality of most of us on this sight, but we are here to assist in anyway we can. Keep in touch. Peace and Grace Ed

Posts.Content: Andy, hang in there you will get better control as the days go by. Right now drink only water. Anything else could be an irritant. I even found that my vitamin C tablet caused problems. I finally had to give up my Soma, because the muscle relaxant caused less control. If you are taking medications I would talk with my pharmacist and doctors about how they could aggravate your problem. I also cut out my diaretic HCTZ that came with my blood pressure medication. Made me pee to much. I haven't given up a shot of Jack Daniels every now an then. A man has got to be a man. Peace and Grace Ed

Posts.Title: 7 days and now counting

Posts.Content: Kazzi61, the outlook is far from bleak. Your husbands situation is very similar to my own. First perineural invasion and seminal vesical involvement is difficult to determine. My outstanding surgeon said he thought I had both after he did an MRI. After surgery neither was the case. I think they prepare you for the worst and when it comes back better than expected he looks like a miracle worker. The gold standard is surgery, because once the prostate is out you can get a pathology report that tells you exactly what you've got. In about 30% of cases the Gleason score is higher. I went from a 7 to a 9. Slow down and both of you take a deep breath. Investigate the options until you both make a decision together. My wife and I learned that it takes two to be sick and your support your husbands final decision for treatment is very important. After surgery it has taken us about 9 months to put all of this behind us, get ready for a life change. I would encourage your husband to get on this site or a similar one and get himself up to speed with men who have this problem and have been through their own cancer walk. Peace and Grace Ed

Posts.Title: Have Full Pathpology/Biopsy Results now-- PLEASE give opions/advice

Posts.Content: Gunny, sorry to hear that you are now part of the club. Now is the time to inform yourself about prostate cancer. When I first found out, I grabbed Dr. Walsh's book and read it in a week and highlighted everything that pretained to me. You have time by the looks of your scores to really investigate your options. If you live close to a good cancer treatment center that has good results with prostate cancer, I would recommend that you check them out. Having a cancer medical team working on your case has advantages and you can get all of your options in one place. I opted for DaVinci because I was a 4+3 and after surgery it came back a 4+5 which happens about 35% of the time. Grab a folder and start keeping all of your test results, take notes when you talk with the doctors, and write down any questions you might have and then get answers. The gentlemen on this site have a wealth of practical experience and are willing to help you out. Keep in touch with updates and questions. Peace and Grace Ed

Posts.Content: I share your thoughts and prayers. The percentage of Vietnam Vets with PCa when compared to the rest of the population is off the charts. It was in the water, we drank lots of water, and Agent Orange exposure has so many health side effects. Your friend should go to the VA with his DD214 and initiate a claim for agent orange exposure, injuries, health issues and PTSD if he hasn't already done so. Peace and Grace Ed Vietnam 71-73

Posts.Title: A very close friend....

Posts.Content: Mikla, the next year is going to get really interesting for you. Important decisions will have to be made and you need to arm yourself with as much information on options and your condition as possible. First I would recommend that you take a week and read Dr. Walsh's book and yellow highlight everything you sense is important to you. FYI, approximately 30% of all prostate cancers are hotter than the original biopsy Gleason score. You have time to research and ask questions. I would encourage you to put together a folder and start collecting copies of all biopsy results, past and present PSA, blood work, collect business cards of all doctors, nurses, radiology, other medical personnel. I would recommend that your wife attend all medical appointments and for her to take copious notes. Running the PCa gauntlet can get confusing and I found out that it took two of us to be sick. You might consider looking into a cancer treatment center in your area that has a good reputation for prostate cancer. Your options are numerous, but they all have side effects. The gentlemen on this sight will give you their best, but we are not medical professionals. Wishing you well and that a cure is in your future. Peace and Grace Ed

Posts.Content: I would make plans for someone to stay with you a couple of days. You will not know how you will feel or the extent of your surgery until after it is completed. If you don't need the person to help you out after the first day you can thank them and let them go. Keep your favorite comfort foods on hand and I would make plans to not leave the house for 3 or 4 days. You will have a catheter and bag to haul around. Record lots of good stuff on the TV or Netflix. Sometimes it takes two to be sick. Hopefully this won't be you case. Peace and Grace Ed

Posts.Title: diagnosed today feb 22nd 2013

Posts.Content: Hello, you might consider a cancer treatment center associated with a university medical school. Lots of up to date information on trials and treatments. Plus it is one stop care. You can usually see a first class surgeon, radiation oncologist, and medical oncologist. The medical team approach offers a lot of information. Talk to all three before you make a decision. Educate yourself, get copies of all lab results, radiology, Dr. reports, and start building a file. You have plenty of time to make an informed decision. PC is a process that may take some time and it does put your life on hold for a few months. Work on this as a team with your husband. It takes two of you working together in concert. My wife handled all the appointments and insurance. I did all the driving and helped maintain the sanity of the situation and went through the medical stuff. Decide what is best for you. Divide and conquer PC. Have your husband start research on the forum. Lots of good information from guys who have been there and know their way around. It was a big help to me and demonstrates that PC treatment is hugely successful. This is not your grandfathers disease and medical advancements are occurring all the time. Peace and Grace Ed

Posts.Content: I would make plans for someone to stay with you a couple of days. You will not know how you will feel or the extent of your surgery until after it is completed. If you don't need the person to help you out after the first day you can thank them and let them go. Keep your favorite comfort foods on hand and I would make plans to not leave the house for 3 or 4 days. You will have a catheter and bag to haul around. Record lots of good stuff on the TV or Netflix. Sometimes it takes two to be sick. Hopefully this won't be you case. Peace and Grace Ed

Posts.Title: First Few Days Home After Surgery - Do I need Someone Their Fulltime?

Posts.Content: Your thoughts are appreciated and encouraging. Those of us who have been diced, sliced and radiated go through our ups and downs. PCa is a lifechanger we can all agree on that subject. This is my support group it and has given me a group of brothers who know my pain. Thank goodness we are living in an age with the internet. Forums like this give freedom from fear of the unknown and information you can't get from a busy doctor. For now my PCa is in check, but when and if it changes I know that this group on the forum will be with me to the end. But for now I am going to "keep on truckin" until I sing Happy Trails for the last time. Peace and Grace fasteddie

Posts.Content: I am nine months past surgery. About 3 months ago I started having strong painful urges to urinate. This happens sometimes 20 to 30 times a day. The urine amount is minimal and the stream is weak. I saw my urologist yesterday and he opened up the meatus(the hole) because it was to small for the scope and now the problem seems worse. Posts.Title: Bladder spasms, frequent strong urges to urinate how can I get past this issue.

Posts.Content: paulplus, sorry to hear that you are a member of the club. Your stats indicate that you are in the early stage of prostate cancer. I would encourage you to get a copy of "The Guide to Surviving Prostate Cancer" by Dr. Walsh. Read it cover to cover and you will have a better understanding of your condition. During your DRE did the urologist feel a nodule or an area of hardness? You definitely have time to research your next step. You may want to get a second opinion from a cancer center that specializes in prostate cancer. This would help you confirm active surveillance as an option. You will need to send your slides to them ahead of time with the pathology report. You need to know that 30%of the time the Gleason score is higher than the biopsy indicates. Keep us posted on updates. I am sure a number of more informed member will respond. Peace and Grace Ed

Posts.Title: Newly diagnosed 10 days ago, insights sought

Posts.Content: My urologist is 200 miles away in Albq. NM and I had an appointment set up with him every six months. He is good about getting me in if needed. My April PSA was <0.08 good. He thought the restriction of the meatus could be the problem and if it doesn't improve he may will scope and widen a minimal restriction on my next visit. I started back on oxybutin tonight to see if it will help with the spasms. I take alot of medications for heart, blood pressure and other problems and adding one more pill is getting tiresome. Plus I like a shot of Makers Mark every night to and alittle spice to life. Since the robotic surgery I have gained 20 lbs and I believe that adds to the problem. Need to get back to my exercising and lose some weight. No sex and depression add to the problem. My grand children keep me going. I want to be around for them. So I keep on truckin. Peace and Grace fasteddie

It will help in our response to your dad's situation. Peace and Grace Ed

Posts.Title: Gleason 9 : Who out there is in the same boat?

Posts.Content: Hey there! Considering the family history and the doubling of PSA it would be reasonable to see a good urologist for his take on the situation. PSA is not the whole story. A DRE and another PSA would give you more information and possible peace of mind. Not to scare you, I went from .8 to 1.6 in three years and had a Gleason 9. I am 22 years older with no family history of PC. So, go figure. When in doubt get a second opinion. Peace and Grace Ed

Posts.Title: Gleason 9 : Who out there is in the same boat?

Posts.Content: Dan, sorry to hear that you are now a member of the club. It is amazing how prostate cancer is different in each individual. Get as much information as you can before you make a decision and from the best medical experts that are available to you. There is a 30% possibility that your Gleason 7 could be more aggressive. Posts.Title: Do I really need treatment?

Posts.Content: Went to a board certified colon/rectal doctor last week and now I am schedule in for surgery to remove an anal papilla and fissure repair. The doctor said that is common because techicians and doctors don't prep or know how to perform the procedure properly. I have lived in misery for 8 months with painful, burning bowel moments, because of an mri tech inserting a prostate coil improperly. My recommendation to anyone going through any of these rectal procedures is to ask the person doing the procedure to throughly prep the area of insertion and to take it slowly. If you sense discomfort, have them back off and reprep the site or the instrument again. Don't let them rip you a new one. I would be interested in hearing from you if you have had similar problems.

Posts.Title: ED Therapy after robotic surgery?

Posts.Content: The person who is writing about his depression is different from the person who initiated this threat. Going from great sex to no sex is frustrating to say the least, but it is one of the things you have to deal with. We are happy that I am still alive considering the Gleason 9 confined to the prostate. The erections may or may not come back but we are going to take advantage of current ED treatments. My prescription insurance gave me 40 20mg Cialis for 3months with 4 refills at $50 per refill. I was wondering if I should split them and take 10mg to make them last longer. My doctor said to do whatever I want as long as I don't exceed 20mg perday. I was wondering if I should be doing the pump and injections at the same time. I start a new insurance deductable in January. Right now I pay nothing for whatever I do. Go after it with a vengence or take it slow and easy? Peace and Grace Ed

Posts.Title: ED Therapy after robotic surgery?

Posts.Content: Chuck, mentioned the "grain of salt" perspective to the information on this site. I have to say that in my case all the grains filled a salt shaker and gave me alot of questions to ask of the medical professionals. I wish that the medical professionals read sites like this and used our personal experiences to assist PCa patients. We encourage visitors to this site to read Dr. Walsh. Walsh slants towards surgery as a solution. We might be better served if there were similar resources emphazing radiation, brachytheraphy, chemo and active surveillance. My question, does this resource exist and if it does, we should mention it along with Dr.Walsh. Happy Trails! Ed

Posts.Title: Factors to consider when deciding on primary treatment...

Posts.Content: I agree, your chances of having prostate cancer are very small. If the the antibiotics don't give you some relief take the next step. The next time you visit your MD doctor have him do a Digital Rectal Exam and have a PSA blood test. If those precedures have good outcomes then you can move on and not have prostate cancer on the mind. Sorry to hear about your pain. Sometimes internal and external hemmoriods can cause discomfort????? or possibly a herniated disc. I have and had both and many of your symptoms.
